column11: Review Text
Slightly underwhelming really. A 5 minute visit after a bit of a wander trying to find it on a hot day. The carving is very intricate and well preserved.

column6: フレクエンとトラベラー
column11: I found Buddiga, the driver introduced on the Jasmine Tour, completely unreliable, so I showed aruco the three featured with pictures and visited. I was also on a school trip to elementary school, so there are definitely things to see. Because it is fenced off, it is easier to see from the temple side, not the entrance side. Beautiful moonstone. Many old stone pillars stand between the accesses, but there is no explanation and I don't know what they mean.

column8: A Sacred Symbol Carved in Stone
column11: The Moonstone in Anuradhapura is one of the most fascinating and spiritual details I encountered during my trip through Sri Lanka’s ancient cities. At first glance, it’s a beautifully carved semicircle at the entrance of a temple — but once you understand its meaning, it becomes truly powerful. Each ring of the Moonstone represents a stage in the Buddhist cycle of life: birth, aging, death, and rebirth. It’s a symbolic reminder that every step toward the temple is a step toward spiritual enlightenment. What makes it even more special is that Moonstones are unique to Sri Lanka — you won’t find them anywhere else in the world. The craftsmanship is incredible, and even after centuries, the carvings are still so detailed and elegant. Tip: Take a moment to stand before it and just observe. Learning about its meaning beforehand makes the experience even more meaningful.
Another quick stop on our tour, this is the best preserved moonstone. Incredible history. You can wander the other ruins, this area wasn’t too busy. We did a bit of haggling at the stores set up.

Basically, with every staircase to a temple finds such a moonstone. However, this one is very well preserved. The animals in the outer circle represent birth, life, disease and death. By making connections with others you learn what suffering and desire is. By being able to distinguish good and evil from each other and doing good, you eventually enter the nirvana, represented by the circle, with the lotus as a symbol.

This is a semi-circular stone slab usually seen at the bottom of staircasesof ancient religious places as well as some ancient royal palaces in Sri Lanka. The Moonstone located at Mahasen's Palace is the best-preserved Moonstone found in Sri Lanka

Nice stone. Beautiful carvings. Good to see it in its context To think that this stone was the entrance to the chapter house being just a small part of the ancient monastery. Gives an understanding of the scale of the ancient city

Maybe two meters in diameter, this ancient entry to a central worship point still has symbolic carvings that can be identified. They demonstrate the stages in life. Hey, it’s worth a visit, but don’t get upset if you miss it. It’s also near the world’s largest swimming pool. Really: You can fit 6 Olympic-size pools in it.

Our guide followed one Sri Lankan authority who associated the moonstone with the cycle of rebirth in Buddhism. Whoever might be right, the semi-circular stone is delicately carved. A surrounding railing is a necessary evil but you can stand close to it to appreciate the fine piece of craftsmanship.
A common motif, you see it all across the ancient temples. It is the stepping stone (literally as well as figuratively)!
Definitely worth a stop, the carvings are beautiful but the (necessary) iron gate to protect them is unsightly

the moonstone, is a unique stone structure that can be observed in Sri Lanka’s ancient Buddhist architecture. This is a semi-circular stone slab with elaborate carvings, usually built at the foot of a staircase or at an entrance to a building. The sadakada pahana located in the ancient city of Anuradhapura is one of the finest and most well-preserved moonstones in the island.

It is discovered and believed that the Sandalada Pahana at Anuradhapura is the one and only man made stone carving which is almost looks alive. This shows how clever and creative people have been in Sri Lanka in ancient times. A must visit place if you are traveling to Anuradhapura
This Moonstone is located in Anuradhapura and still remains a clear stone carving, which was made  2000 years ago.
Moonstones are an important part of temple architecture.  This one is both quite intricate and well preserved
The moonstone was really interesting either tuk tuk or if you have a car and driver stop and have a look.

Just one small part of the extensive site. All the Temples have a moonstone, this one is the oldest and intricately decorated. It is protected by an iron surround but still viewable. Go fir a glimpse if you have time.
It's hard to review each part of the Anuradhapura site as this takes 20 minutes to look around as part of the whole experience.
A very old carving that served as an entrance ground stone to the very old Temple/ building. Talks about life's journey and other life's problems. Really very interesting.
There is literally very little here other than the stone foootprint of the former building on the ground. There’s some nice ornamental stonework at the entrance steps but that’s about it.

The ancient moonstone is one of the most stunning stone carvings of Sri Lanka. It's fine chiselled art is just a stunning. Don't miss this piece of ancient art when you are at the sacred city, it's worth the ride!

THIS needs to be on your list of things to see. Its beyond stunning and a real piece of art. Try and get there when you can have time to really look at it without the place teaming with fellow tourists.

The design of the moonstone has undergone many changes over time, But the moonstones show the highest level of creativity towards the end of the Anuradhapura Era. The moonstones in the monasteries where the forest-dwelling monks lived maintained the blank semi-circular shape. The moonstones of Anuradhapura Era, the outer edge is designed with a ring of flames and below that is a ring filled with 4 types of animals – The elephant, the horse, the lion, and the bull chasing each other. Some moonstones show these beasts in their own semi-circular band. The next is a semi-circle of a creeper with a wavy stem with foliage. Next is a line of swans with a twig of flower and a leaf on their mouth. Next is again a floral pattern and at the center is lotus with petals all around the semi-circle on the moonstone. That the outer ring of fire represents the never-ending life and the pains of passion associated with it. The four animals represent the four noble truths (“Chathurarya Sathya”) which are birth, old age, disease, and death. The leafy creeper next to it is a reminder of desires which creates little fruits but only foliage Next is a motif of swans. It is said that the swan is capable of separating out milk from a mixture of water and milk. He who understands (conquer) four noble truths can easily filter the good from the bad like the swan filters out milk. Once you do that you are capable of attaining the “Nibbana” represented by the lotus.(As per Professor Paranavithana)

It is a half-circle shaped stone covered with eight lines of delicate animal and floral carvings. It seems to be a very popular architectural motif and you will find it in front of many old and new buildings, all over the island.
These carvings made in stone is beautiful. You will find the a copy of this in many private and public entrances.

Situated in the Abharagiri Monastery the much loved moonshine is a very popular and worthy part of any visit to ancient Anuradhapura. IThe minastery dates from the 9th century I think and the moonshine is  so well preserved, I'm not sure it could possibly be nearly as old! It is a ceremonial entrance stone to the ruined temple behind with flames along it's diameter to represent life and various sacred animals inset. A stunning piece of craftmanship and well worth a call.
It is really magnificat. There are many moonstones around Sri Lanka, and I really saw few of them, but this one is really astonishing. Worth visiting!

The moonstone is a cool object, even if its in hot sun it doesn't get heated. Not sure if i had seen this one, made the tuktuk driver showed me something else and mentioned as moonstone. I pointed out at a sign with moonstone and he told me that it has been shifted.

This is the best ever identified moonstone in Sri Lanka. This is situated in Abhayagiri Monastery premises at the entrance of Biso Maligaya. The moonstone is very elaborative. And it is very smooth, neat and precise. It is really a perfect example for the height of the art of stone carvings in ancient Sri Lanka. There are so many places to visit nearby this place, therefore, this is really a highly recommended place to visit in anuradhapura.
There a many moonstones around Sri Lanka, and this is probably the most famous one. It's easily found,  and near many of the other sites of the ancient city.

Moonstone name is due to its shape & design. Beautifully carved semicircular slab placed at bottom of staircases & entrances of building. This is situated northwest of Abhayagiri Dagoba in ruins of residencial complex of monks. It represents life cycle Its structure has half lotus in center surrounded by concentric bands. first band is procession of swans,than foliage band,than third band has carvings of elephants,lions,horses,bulls. fourth outermost band has carvings of flames. Beautifully carved . No seperate entry ticket

We were told this was one of the extraordinary treasures here: It is a well-preserved ornamented stone plate with different animals and dwarfs. I felt that the surrounding momuments might have spoiled me a bit so that I was not so impressed, although this stone is more than 1,000 years old.

The moonstone stands in a fenced enclosure in front of a ruined “palace?” that  has only its support pillars standing.  It is is very good condition and the carvings are quite clear. Behind it is a set of delicatelycarved steps with dancing “dwarves”on them. There are other moonstones on the complex but this is the best.

There are many nice moonstones in Anuradhapura and this is one of the best.  But it's where all the tour groups go, so head out to Moonstone 2, which is just a few hundred meters away in a part of the park that hasn't been so restored.

The moonstone is worth seeing, while the rest of the complex is mostly ruined bases and a few pillars.  However, it's a nice area filled with butterflies and dragonflies.  There are stalls and touts nearby but they're still pretty quiet.
Moonstone is a good example for creativity of ancient architecture in Sri Lanka. It is situated in Anuradhapura.
Moonstone or Sandakada pahana, Anuradhapuraya is an unbelievable creative of the ancient kings. This is must see thing during the Anurdhapur tour.
There was something magical about the elaborately carved moon-stone. We were lucky enough to have a guide who was able to explain what the different rings represented so this made it extra special.
Located a short distance from the Samadhi Pilimaya. You have to travel a short distance, maybe about 1 km along the paved road.
Another must see item of ancient history.  The design and art work is to be admired.  still preserved in entirety
Great architecture and well protected by UNESCO, nice to see the marvel creations of our ancestors, worth spending time.

This is the first capital of Sri Lanka. 2500 years ago King Pandukabhaya built this. Abhayagiriya stupa (pagoda), Ruwanweliseya stupa (Pagoda), Isurumuniya Temple, Tissa Lake Etc. World most oldest recorded tree (Sri Maha Bodhi) and lot of ancient Ruins can see there
i see this one in all old temple.this one having dong story.with this animals having different meaning,

Moon stone or sadakada pahana in sinhala is found at the entrance to a temple or at the beginning of a staircase. The circle of animals have meanings, when you visit that place a person from archeological department will describe it to you.

The moonstone was usually found at the entrance to a temple or at the staircase. The circle of animals have meanings of life, growth, energy, poser and forbearance. Really beautiful to see the intact piece preserved here.
Walk through the souvenir market to get to it. In a nice setting amongst the ruins. The animal figures carved into this are very impressive

I'm so glad they have fenced it off so you can't walk on it. I was able to 10 years back. This is a detailed sculpture of a half lotus carved in the centre with a procession of swans, followed by four animals; elephants, lions, horses, and bulls. The four animals symbolize the four stages in life: growth, energy, power and forbearance.
The semi circle carving seems just that.  That is until the explanation of the quest for nirvana is explained.  A great experience and a help to understanding cultures.
advisable to go early in the morning as possible or late in the evening as with the hot sun it's difficult to visit these places
A must visit !! The half circle shaped stone bears several carvings of ancient art such as Palapathi, elephants and other historical drawings. Dress code required.
One of the most beautiful and characteristic moonstones in Sri Lanka, and an excellent example of its kind. Not really awe-inspiring from up close.
If you happen to be in the area, check it out.  It is a semi-circle at the base of stairs with interesting carvings.

The Moonstone This rock carving at the entrance to an ancient ruin depicts the Buddhist belief in reincarnation. The outer ring is a procession of animals beginning and ending with the elephant representing rebirth, next comes the horse or the travel through life followed by the lion depicting old age and the decline in life. Finally comes the water buffalo representing death. This sequence is repeated three times with the final elephant showing yet another reincarnation. It is said that Buddha endured 550 incarnations before reaching Nirvana. The next ring is a tangle of vines depicting the passage through life with all its entanglements, the next ring are all swans with there reputed ability to separate milk from a mixture of milk and water as a sign of purification. All very thought provoking. Here I must state that this is my interpretation of our guides explanation as I am not an expert on Buddhism.
Well worth seeing. All carvings are easily recognisable and this does not look as it is centuries old as it is so well preserved

This is an original moonstone which looks beautiful. Everything is symmetrical and if you have a tour guide, they will explain to you what the stone means. There are so many replicas of the moonstone but this is the real thing.
An individual animal semcircles means passages of our lives. As you can see some of the animals explain wisdom some of them explain power and so on...
The carvings of animals - elephants, horses - are beautifully and symmetrically done and well maintained by the authorities
You'll see many copies of the Moonstone in hotels etc while in the area but this is the original and well worth going to see.
When you think about the craftsmanship on these Moonstones, it is remarkable. Lots of detail. The ruins in this area are worth seeing.

The Moonstone is a piece of rock carving that is placed near the base of steps. You can see many such stones in Anuradhapura and Polonaruwa. This particular piece, however, is one of the finest in the country. There are rock carvings of animals on the disc, each occupying a different layer. They have religious significance. The steps also have interesting carvings of little creatures. To know more, you probably have to read up (or get a guide). I find there are many more interesting relics in the area.
Its good to know the details regarding Moonstone and how ancient people used that ones. It seems like everything they had significances !!

Our guide did a wonderful job describing this moonstone and the history surrounding this carving.  Very interesting.  If you have a good guide, the true value of this site becomes apparent.  Otherwise, you might consider taking a pass. To

This is a ancient carving made in Rock stones just infront of Entrance to Bhuddhist places of worship depicting many layers of Elephants, Horse. Lion, Swan , Lotus Flower etc. Historians think the carvings symbolise a religious meaning.  Moonstone is just a vague translation to English. Sinhalese meaning says "Half Moon Lamp"

A beautiful ancient piece of architecture, with carvings of animals & flowers on a stone.Many legends surround these carving. Although this carving is very old, it has been preserved well. As it is in the historical site many people visit this place. A must see when you visit other religious & historical monuments in the sacred area & ruins of Anuradhapura as the carvings are really well done.
